list_page_teaser: This gallery contains spiritual portraits of a few famous American celebrities.  Click to learn more!
description_html:
Here are a few images of real people.

Hopefully everyone will recognize these names and appreciate the ability to see their personalities.
story_html:
These images are based on some dvds I found at the Denver Public Library. I chose these individuals because their stories were readily available and believe most, if not all, visitors will recognize their names and have some knowledge of them.

I plan to add more portraits to this gallery soon. To keep up to date and learn when I post new images, follow this site on social media or join the SeeOurMinds.com email list!

image_list.title: Mark Twain (Samuel Clemens)
image_list.subtitle_html: Humorist and Author of Great American Novels
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Mark Twain's spiritual portrait shows he is idealistic and very passionate.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Mark Twain's dominant personality trait, his openness to ideas.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  He demonstrated this trait when he became a strident anti-imperialist later in life, when the Philippine–American War in 1899-1902 made him realize American imperialism was contrary to the American ideals of independence and self-government outlined in documents such as the Declaration of Independence and Abraham Lincoln's Gettysburg Address.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Mark Twain's auxiliary personality trait, his warmth, passion, and amiability.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  He demonstrated this trait in his ability to feel and convey a range of emotions, from ironic and humorous to tragic and sad, in his writings and lectures.
image_list.story_intro_html: Mark Twain is the nom de plume of writer and humorist Samuel Langhorne Clemens. Clemens was born ....

image_list.title: Woody Allen
image_list.subtitle_html: Comedian, Filmmaker, Auteur
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Born Allan Stewart Konigsberg, Woody has averaged putting out one film per year for fourty years.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Woody's dominant trait, his compassion and warmth.  In Introverts, the dominant trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  He demonstrates this trait in the way he treats the actors and actresses in his films with compassion.
image_list.explain_aux: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Woody's auxiliary trait, iNtuition: idealism; openness to ideas; preference for ideas over facts.  In Introverts, the auxiliary trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a vertical line to represent this, because it is more evident than the dominant function.  He demonstrates this trait in the way he is willing to make films of varying types, rather than stick to a tried and true genre (e.g., comedies).
image_list.story_intro_html: While he was still in high school, Woody Allen started writing one-liners for established comedians. This led to writing for ....

image_list.title: Frank Lloyd Wright
image_list.subtitle_html: Greatest American Architect of All Time
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Frank Lloyd Wright's spiritual portrait shows he is very logical and a bit idealistic.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Frank Lloyd Wright's dominant personality trait, his moderate preference for logic over emotion.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  He demonstrated this trait in his ability to create rational and logical architectural drawings that were also beautiful and original.
image_list.explain_aux: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Frank Lloyd Wright's auxiliary personality trait, his preference for ideas over facts.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  He demonstrated this trait when he created houses later identified to be part of the Prairie School style of architecture.  This style incorporated a modern and uniquely American aesthetic, encouraging the use of horizontal bands that integrate with the buildings' surroundings and echo the flat landscape of the American prairie.
image_list.story_intro_html: In 1991 the American Institute of Architects recognized Frank Lloyd Wright as the greatest American architect of all time — 32 years after....

image_list.title: Eleanor Roosevelt
image_list.subtitle_html: First Lady and Wife of FDR
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Eleanor Roosevelt's spiritual portrait shows she is compassionate and idealistic.  These qualities show why she showed concern for and wanted to help others, especially those who were disadvantaged, have a better future.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Eleanor's dominant trait, her warmth and compassion.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  She demonstrated this trait in the way she cared for people, in her family and in all of America as a whole.
image_list.explain_aux: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Eleanor's auxiliary trait, her idealism.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  She demonstrated this trait in the way she would always try to help others work for and have a better future.
image_list.story_intro_html: An orphan at 10, Eleanor Roosevelt's story is quite inspirational....

image_list.title: Steve Bannon
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Steve Bannon's spiritual portrait shows he is very cold and driven by his idealism.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Steve's dominant personality trait, his cool-headedness and objectivity.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  He demonstrated this coldness when, in his role as a Senior Advisor to Donald Trump, he worked to restrict immigration to the United States.
image_list.explain_aux: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Steve's auxiliary personality trait, his tendency to see the world through an idealistic lens.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  This trait is reflected in his political beliefs, which are paleoconservative and nationalistic.
image_list.story_intro_html: This image of the personality of Steve Bannon shows he is an extreme ....
image_list.story_html:
This story comes from the book Visualizing Politicians' Personalities, 2019 Incumbents and Candidates by Tom W. Hartung, © 2019, all rights reserved.

THIS IMAGE OF THE PERSONALITY OF STEVE BANNON shows he is an extreme version of the largest group of personalities featured in this ebook – the group that includes Elizabeth Warren, Kamala Harris, Michael Bennet, and Mike Pence.

In the opening chapter of his book Bannon: Always the Rebel, Keith Koffler introduces Steve as someone who is fearsomely learned, and always reading to learn more. He writes that Steve is most interested in Western civilization, its Judeo-Christian tradition, and his own Catholic faith [p. 2]. Elaborating on this, the author mentions The Imitation of Christ by Thomas a Kempis and The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire by Edward Gibbon as being among Steve’s favorite books of all time.

Keith Koffler writes of talking to people who knew Steve when he was growing up in Richmond, Virginia and who told him Steve was highly competitive, aggressive, and would pick fights with Tough kids, older than him [pp. 14-15]. The author states Steve seemed to relish combat and quotes Steve’s brother Mike as saying he would take on as many as eight others at a time [p. 15].

In Chapter 13, Bannon at Breitbart, Keith Koffler describes how Steve met Andrew Breitbart in 2004 at the Liberty Film Festival. Steve was screening his new film, In the Face of Evil: Reagan's War in Word and Deed, and Andrew loved it. Quoting Steve, Keith Koffler says an excited Andrew exclaimed You get it, culture's upriver from things. You're Leni Reifenstahl [p. 136].

Leni Reifenstahl was the director of famous Nazi propaganda films like Triumph of the Will.

STEVE’S COLD SPIRITUAL PORTRAIT REFLECTS HIS COLD PERSONALITY. In Chapter 7, A Flawed Visionary, Keith Koffler briefly covers Steve’s three failed marriages, revealing he remains extremely close to his daughter Maureen, a West Point graduate who served in Iraq [p. 69]. The author goes on to quote Ben Shapiro, who had worked as an editor at Breitbart News, as saying Steve is a vindictive, nasty figure, infamous for verbally abusing supposed friends and threatening enemies [p. 72]. Keith Koffler then goes on to explain how Ben and Steve had a falling out over an incident involving Breitbart reporter Michelle Fields and Corey Lewandowski.

Ben Shapiro’s vindictive assessment of Steve does not necessarily mean Steve is a bad guy – even though precisely what that means varies with one’s perspective. Later in his book, Keith Koffler takes quotes from an appearance Steve made on Sean Hannity’s show on Fox News in 2010 in which Steve claims the Tea Party is the voice of the working man and woman in this country [p. 116].

A desire to support the working man may sound strange coming from someone who is more conservative than progressive, so on the show, Steve elaborated on his thinking. Keith Koffler quotes him as saying It's the decent people who fight our wars, who run our civic organizations, who are the backbone of this country. The difference is, unlike forward-looking progressives, Steve claims these people have 1950s values [p. 116].

In Chapter 4 of Fire and Fury, the first chapter in Michael Wolff’s book dedicated to Steve, he reveals some of his take on Steve’s character. He confirms Steve is tough, writing that however smart and even charismatic he could be at times, Steve was not necessarily a nice guy [p. 57].

MEETING ANDREW BREITBART IN 2004 led Steve to meeting the man who offered Bannon the ultimate opportunity: Robert Mercer. Michael Wolff writes of how Steve’s interest in conservative film-making was trying to separate a fool from his money, and that the extremely wealthy Bob Mercer and his daughter Rebekah had set themselves up as almost professional fools. [p.58].

While Bob was an ultimate quant [p. 58], it was Rebekah Mercer...who defined the family. In his candid style, Michael Wolff quotes an anonymous staffer inside Donald Trump’s White House as saying of Rebekah that She's nuts...nuts...full-fledged...like whoa, ideologically there is no conversation with her [p. 59, all ellipsis appear here as they do in the original].

This anonymous comment lends some color to Joshua Green’s reference in his book, Devil’s Bargain, to the Mercers as being eccentric [p. 135]. Joshua Green also writes of how Robert and his daughter Rebekah became benefactors of Breitbart News, and when Andrew died in 2012 at age 43, the Mercers gave their blessing for Bannon to step in and take over the site [p. 131].

Joshua Green states that, before creating Breitbart News, Andrew Breitbart helped Matt Drudge to publish the Drudge Report and Arianna Huffington [to] launch the liberal Huffington Post [p. 85].

THE MERCERS COULD SEE THAT STEVE IS PROUD of being a hard-ass – and hence a perfect fit for the rough-and tumble journalism practiced at Breitbart News. As Joshua Green states early in his book, Bannon's personal motto was ‘Honey badger don't give a shit,’ [p. 4].

In Chapter 6 of Devil’s Bargain – interestingly entitled The Alt-Kochs – the author describes how, during a party at Breitbart News celebrating the Conservative Political Action Conference in 2015, Steve had arranged a gift for his guests. As guests left the party, a doorman handed out ... a silver hip flask with ‘Breitbart’ imprinted above an image of a honey badger, the Breitbart mascot [p. 131].

Perhaps the best evidence of Steve’s view of himself as a fierce leader comes in Joshua Green’s mention of an oil painting of Bannon dressed as Napoleon in his study at the Tuileries. The painting is a gift from Nigel Farage, a nationalist-minded friend [p. 6].

At the time of this writing in 2019, Nigel Farage leads Britain’s Brexit party.

THE PROFILE FOR THIS IMAGE IS BASED ON the book Bannon: Always the Rebel, by Keith Koffler, 2017. The book Fire and Fury by Michael Wolff provided inspiration for learning about Steve and creating this image, and Devil's Bargain by Joshua Green provided additional material for this story.

To learn more about Kamala and other contemporary politicians, buy Visualizing Politicians' Personalities, 2019 Incumbents and Candidates by Tom W. Hartung online today at amazon.com!
